utterances: Seoul 1988, Canadian sailor Lawrence Lemieux is traveling through strong 35-knot wind.
He's in position to win a medal, [and] then his boat sails off course.
Lawrence Lemieux, tell us what you saw then in the water?
One of the boats from another race that was - we were sharing the race course with was in trouble.
And it's a two-person boat.
And I saw the boat was upside down, but there was only one of the two crew members on the boat.
I realized that one of them was missing, and it was sort of a matter of half looking around for him while I was still competing in half.
Just basically coming across him and saw him in the water, a long way from his boat.
So I had a decision to make.
The decision was whether to compete or whether to help.
Which did you choose?
Well, I obviously chose to help.
I was yelling at him, Do you need help?
But the problem is he can't hear.
There's too much noise with the wind going by and everything.
You know, at the point when I saw the other crew member in the water, only then it became obvious that, you know, he needed help.
He was going to be lost at sea.
And there's a lot of wind, and a lot of waves, and there's a lot of boats in trouble.

So, there wasn't really enough rescue boats around to deal with all the problems, and it was hard enough to see the marker buoys that are eight-foot high fluorescent orange buoys, let alone a little dark head bobbing in the water.
So I thought, well, I better grab him now before nobody can find him.
You grabbed them, you saved them.
The head of the Olympic Committee created a sportsmanship medal just for you and what you did.
Did it mean as much to you as winning what you might have won had you continued competing?

Well, yes and no. Obviously, it would mean a lot to be recognized for your achievements in the sport that you choose, but on the other hand, this story, I think, a lot of people remember every four years, it comes up.
And, you know, there's programs like yours that are highlighting it, so I suppose if I had won a medal, I would have been all but forgotten by now.

Hi, there.
Hello, Ms. Gray.

There is an ominous milestone to mark in the heart of America.
The medical examiner of Cuyahoga County, Ohio, says 52 people were killed there last month because they overdosed on opioid painkillers, including heroin.
Because a few toxicology reports are still pending, the final number of deaths for September is expected to exceed 52, which would make a grim new monthly record for the county.
And the medical examiner has 14 suspected deaths by overdose in just the first week of October.
At least 385 people in Cuyahoga County have died this year from opioid overdoses.
The medical examiner says they're on a course to see more than 500 people die from heroin and other opioid overdoses this year.
Cleveland.com tried to document some of the human toll this epidemic of deaths has taken and the wreckage it leaves those who live on.
To read just a few is to unroll a catalogue of tragedies.
Brandy Bradley of Cleveland, a 34-year-old mother of two, received prescriptions for painkillers, depression and sleeplessness following the birth of her first child at 16.
When those ran out, she sought out street dealers who told her heroin was just $20 while pills cost 50.
She switched.
Brandi Bradley died last summer, discovered by her 18-year-old son.
She also leaves a 5-year-old daughter.
It's the children left behind that hurt the most, her sister Karrie Bradley told Cleveland.com.
Brett Taylor was 30.
He was star quarterback of his high school team in Akron, where football is a kind of religious faith.
But he suffered football injuries, did hot, heavy work in construction after high school, lost one of his sisters to drugs and started to drink too much and do heroin.
Brett Taylor died of an overdose last year, leaving behind three sons who may be too young to ever remember him and a father so broken, he died of a heart attack nine months after Brett.
And Megan Wheeler was also 30.
Her friends remember her as sweet, smart and spirited, but when she broke her jaw in a car crash in 2005, doctors prescribed opioids.
When they ran out.
she turned to stealing.
She went to jail a few times and treatment programs, but couldn't stay clean and sober and also died last year.

Her mother, Nancy Krasienko, who now has Megan's two children, told us she devotes her life to them and to telling others her daughter's story and those of others caught in the malevolent, merciless grip of drugs.
We have to speak their names, she said, 'cause they would want us to do that.
